Graphical abstract Bimetallic supported catalysts can show synergistic effects compared to their monometallic constituents. However, it is challenging to produce bimetallic catalysts with a uniform nanoparticle distribution over the support, while ensuring each nanoparticle contains both metals. A promising strategy is to use impregnation precursors that facilitate uniform distribution of both metals over a support. In this work, citrate-based precursors were studied to prepare bimetallic Pd-Ni nanoparticles supported on SBA-15 mesoporous silica. Amongst others, cryo-electron microscopy demonstrated the excellent distribution of Ni citrate precursor after drying. Co-impregnation with Ni citrate precursor and Pd(OAc)2 or Pd(NH3)4(NO3)2 produced well-distributed Pd-Ni nanoparticles with a narrow particle size distribution. Extensive characterization with STEM-EDX, EXAFS and TPR showed that the type of Pd precursor controlled the Pd to Ni nanoscale intimacy. CO2 hydrogenation experiments demonstrated that increasing Pd-Ni intimacy decreased the activity. Our strategy to produce uniform Pd-Ni nanoparticles using citric acid is relevant also for other bimetallic systems. Keywords Bimetallic catalyst Heterogeneous catalysis Pd-Ni Data availability The data that support the findings of this study are available from the corresponding author upon reasonable request. 1 Introduction Bimetallic nanoparticles can show unique catalytic properties [1–3]. For instance, adding dilute amounts of the expensive but highly active Pd to a more abundant base metal (e.g. Fe, Co, Ni) hydrogenation catalyst can boost activity, improve selectivity and decrease the required reduction temperature [4]. Pd-Ni nanoparticles have been studied in selective hydrogenation reactions of CO2 [4–6], nitroarene [7,8], vinyl acetylene [9], 2-methyl-3-butyn-2-ol [8] and cinnamaldehyde [10]. The improved catalytic activity and selectivity observed in these studies are often ascribed to the atomic-scale interplay between the Pd and Ni phases. However, with industrially relevant preparation techniques such as impregnation it is difficult to control the distribution of different metals, a necessity to achieve catalysts with an optimal performance; All metal nanoparticles throughout a sample must have the same Pd-to-Ni ratio. Thus, uniformity in this context encompasses three crucial aspects: the even distribution of Pd and Ni, the spatial distribution of nanoparticles over the support and the particle size distribution. For the Pd-Ni system, there are a few reports on producing bimetallic catalysts with incipient wetness impregnation using the nitrate salts as precursors [7,11], but producing Ni nanoparticles that are homogeneously distributed over the support and have a uniform particle size using a Ni nitrate precursor has not been achieved [12]. Aqueous Pd nitrate solutions are intrinsically unstable and are prone to colloidal PdO particle formation [13]. Moreover, a mismatch in decomposition or reduction conditions required to decompose different metal precursors or reduce their respective metal oxides may lead to severe sintering or segregation of the metals [3]. A strategy to control the metal distribution, is to use an additive to enforce a uniformly distributed precursor phase over the support during drying and activation. Its effectiveness has been demonstrated for Ni/SiO2 catalyst preparation using citric acid; NiCO3 dissolved in citric acid as precursor solution produced well-dispersed Ni nanoparticles on silica supports such as MCM-41 and SBA-15 [14,15]. A viscous immobile gel was suggested to form upon evaporation of water, thereby keeping the Ni phase in place during drying and activation [12]. While the combustion of citric acid, an exothermic calcination process, is less favorable industrially than the endothermic decomposition of nitrate precursors, the ability to control the nanoparticle size and uniformity may outweigh this drawback. Therefore, it is interesting to study the use of citric acid for distribution of bimetallic nanoparticles, an approach already reported for preparation of Cu-Ni nanoparticles [16]. Although there are no reports of using citrate assisted impregnation for producing catalysts like Pd-Ni. Additionally, measuring how the metals are atomically distributed in the bimetallic catalysts is challenging. Transmission Electron Microscopy with elemental analysis can reveal the size, distribution and metal composition of nanoparticles but is mostly reserved to local and ex-situ analyses. Bulk probing techniques have other limitations; i.e. X-ray diffraction requires sufficiently large crystallites and Temperature Programmed Reduction changes a catalyst during the characterization process. Therefore, a multitude of local (STEM-EDX) and bulk-probing (like TPR, XRD, XPS and XAS) techniques are required to characterize Pd and Ni phases present in Pd-Ni catalysts [7,10,11,17,18]. In this work the use of citric acid containing precursors for preparation of Pd-Ni nanoparticles was studied. The silica support, SBA-15, with its well-defined pore size and ordered porosity facilitated to study nanoparticle formation through all stages of preparation with electron microscopy. Using advanced characterization, the citrate precursors were found to produce homogeneously distributed metal species over the support after drying, translating to a uniform distribution of metal nanoparticles with a narrow particle size distribution after activation. Control over Pd and Ni intimacy was achieved by varying the Pd precursor. CO2 hydrogenation was used to verify the Pd-Ni intimacy, as the activity significantly decreased with Pd-Ni mixing in the nanoparticles. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals SBA-15 (850 m2/g; 1 mL/g pore volume) was prepared using a procedure based on Lee et al. 2010 [19]. NiCO3 (98 %, anhydrous) was purchased from Alfa Caesar and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (99 %) from Sigma-Aldrich. Palladium acetate; Pd(OAc)2 (99.5 %, trimeric) and Pd tetraammine; Pd(NH3)4(NO3)2 (10 wt% aqueous solution) precursors were also purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. A 25 vol% citric acid solution was prepared by dissolving 4.55 g of citric acid monohydrate (99.9 %, Sigma-Aldrich) in 7.05 mL Milli-Q deionized water (18 MΩ·cm) to yield a 10.0 mL 25 vol% (and 35.9 wt%) citric acid solution. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Prior to impregnation, SBA-15 was dried at 170 °C in vacuum for 1 h. Then, this support was impregnated at 90 % pore volume as determined by N2 physisorption. Monometallic Ni/SBA-15 references were prepared by impregnation with either an aqueous Ni(NO3)2·6H2O solution (Ni nitrate precursor) or a solution of NiCO3 in 25 vol% citric acid (Ni citrate precursor, 1:1.3 Ni:Citr molar) in both cases 1.7 M Ni. The targeted loading of Ni for these catalysts was 10 wt% Ni. For bimetallic Pd-Ni/SBA-15 nanoparticle preparation, there were two precursor formulations: A) Pd(OAc)2 (Sigma Aldrich, 99.5 %, trimeric) with NiCO3 (Alfa Caesar, 98 %, anhydrous) in a 25 vol% citric acid solution and B) Pd(NH3)4(NO3)2 with NiCO3 in a 25 vol% citric acid solution. The catalysts are denoted by their Pd precursor and are therefore called A) Pd-Ni Ac-Citr and B) Pd-Ni NH3-Citr respectively. As the solubility of Pd(OAc)2 was limited, the loadings of Pd and Ni were chosen as 0.9 wt% and 5 wt% respectively in the Pd-Ni Ac-Citr sample. The loadings of Pd and Ni were 1.8 wt% Pd and 10 wt% Ni for the Pd-Ni NH3-Citr sample. After impregnation and 12 h drying under vacuum at room temperature, the samples were calcined at 350 °C for 2 h (2 °C/min ramp) in air with 300 mL/min·gcat flow rate with exception of the monometallic Ni nitrate sample for which the gas atmosphere was 1 % NO/N2. Subsequent reduction was performed at 450 °C for 2 h (2 °C/min ramp) in 300 mL/min·gcat 10 % H2/N2 flow. 2.3 Characterization Impregnated and dried samples were characterized using Cryogenic Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (Cryo-STEM) using a FEI Talos F200x with 200 kV acceleration voltage. The samples were loaded on a holey carbon Cu grid (Agar-scientific) immediately after the drying step. Then, the grids were immersed in liquid N2 to freeze the samples in their dried state. The supercooled grid was then inserted in an actively cooled Cryo-EM holder with thermocouple. After reaching a stable temperature of −184 °C, the blank, Ni nitrate impregnated and Ni citrate impregnated SBA-15 samples were imaged with High Angular Annular Dark-Field Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (HAADF-STEM). Calcined, reduced and passivated Ni and Pd-Ni samples were imaged using the same electron microscope but at room temperature. The particle sizes were determined by measuring ∼ 100 particles per sample in BF-TEM micrographs in ImageJ. The number averaged particle size and standard deviation were determined by: d TEM ± σ TEM = 1 N ∑ i = 0 N d i ± 1 N - 1 ∑ i = 1 N d i - d TEM 2 In which d i is the measured diameter and σ i the standard deviation. Pd-Ni samples were embedded in acrylic resin and microtomed (in ∼ 70 nm sections) to visualize a representative section of the catalysts grains and reduce pore shrinkage of the SiO2 by the electron beam during prolonged exposure. Elemental maps were made using Energy Dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) with Super-X G1 EDX detectors using VeloxTM imaging software. The EDX counts were background subtracted and the counts per pixel were averaged over 3x3 pixels to increase visibility. The surface areas and pore volumes of the impregnated and dried Ni citrate and Ni nitrate samples were analyzed with N2 physisorption on a Micromeritics TriStar II Plus instrument. Pore size distributions were calculated using a Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) analysis with a Faas correction and assuming 0.5 for the fraction of open cylindrical pores. Both the isotherms and the BJH plots for the Ni nitrate and Ni citrate impregnated samples were corrected for the added weight of dried precursor compared to the blank SBA-15. Both the drying and decomposition processes of the nickel monometallic and Pd-Ni bimetallic nanoparticles were in-situ followed with thermogravimetric analysis and coupled mass spectrometry (TGA-MS). The impregnated samples were prepared in the same way as reported in the previous section (2.2 catalyst preparation); the monometallic samples were SBA-15 impregnated with Ni nitrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O dissolved in water) and Ni citrate (NiCO3 dissolved in a 25 vol% citric acid solution) precursors. The bimetallic samples consisted of SBA-15 impregnated with either Pd(OAc)2 and NiCO3 dissolved in a 25 vol% citric acid or Pd(NH3)4(NO3)2 (aq) with NiCO3 dissolved in a 25 vol% citric acid. Typically, ∼2 mg of these impregnated samples was weighed in a Pt sample holder and placed in a TA instruments TGA 5500. The sample was then heated from 30 to 500 °C in 20 % O2/Ar with a 5 °C/min heating rate. The effluent was monitored with a Cirrus Minilab Benchtop mass spectrometer. Reduction of calcined catalysts was probed with a Micrometrics Autochem II 2920 Chemisorption Analyzer. Typically, ∼ 50 mg of 75–150 μm-sieved, calcined sample was first dried at 120 °C under 50 mL/min Ar flow for 30 min and left to cool down to room temperature. The samples were then heated with a ramp of 5 °C/min to 600 °C in 5 % H2/Ar (50 mL/min) flow while recording with a Thermal Conductivity Detector. XAS studies on calcined, reduced and passivated catalysts were performed at the Pd K-edge on the ROCK beamline at SOLEIL synchrotron, Paris [20]. The monochromator used was a Si(111) crystal channel-cut monochromator. The oscillation amplitude was set to 0.35° for the Pd K-edge to cover around 1000 eV after the edge. The spectra were collected in transmission using ionization chambers (Ohyo Koken) filled with N2/Ar (50/50 v/v) for the Pd K-edge. A Pd foil, placed between the 2nd and 3rd ionization chambers, were measured simultaneously for the data alignment. XAS data was processed using the Demeter software package [21,22]. The metal loadings of Pd and Ni in the bimetallic catalysts was determined with Inductively Coupled Plasma (ICP) analysis, performed at Mikroanalytisches laboratorium Kolbe. 2.4 Hydrogenation of CO2 to CH4 CO2 hydrogenation was measured using a 16-reactor high-throughput Avantium Flowrence reactor. Typically, 25 mg of reduced catalyst (sieved in 75–150 μm grains) was mixed with 150 mg, 212–425 μm sieved SiC and loaded in a 2.6 mm inner-diameter stainless steel reactor. The samples were first re-reduced in a 6,000 h−1 GHSV 5 % H2/N2 flow at 450 °C for 2 h. The temperature was then lowered to 100 °C before changing the atmosphere to 4:1 H2:CO2 with He as internal standard for the GC (75:19:5 H2:CO2:He) at a flow-rate of 6000 h−1. The reactor was then pressurized to 30 bar and the test started with a 450 °C 2 h conditioning step. The sample was then cooled down to 250 °C and the temperature was increased every 4 h with 50 °C steps until 450 °C was reached. An online Agilent 7890B gas chromatograph analyzed the products every 15 min. The Turn-over-frequency calculations are detailed in Section S6 CO2 hydrogenation in the supplementary information. 3 Results & discussion 3.1 Ni nitrate versus Ni citrate precursor decomposition There are strong indications that citrate-based precursors improve the Ni nanoparticle distribution over the support by formation of a viscous gel compared to more prevalent Ni nitrate precursors [14,15], but the manner in which the citric acid-based precursors impact the distribution of Ni over the support is not well understood. Thermo-Gravimetric Analysis coupled with Mass Spectrometry (TGA-MS) was used (Fig. 1 ) to investigate the drying and decomposition processes of the impregnated Ni ex-citrate and ex-nitrate samples. For both precursors, two mass loss regimes were identified; one that is associated with the loss of water and another that is related to the decomposition of the citrate or nitrate precursor (indicated in blue and purple in Fig. 1 respectively). The corresponding MS plots in c) and d) also reflect those regimes; H2O formation between 30 and 150 °C represents the drying phase and decomposition products are observed between 150 and 320 °C. The decrease in relative mass during drying and decomposition and the corresponding decomposition products are different. The mass lost during drying is larger for the Ni nitrate sample than for the citrate precursor, while the relative mass lost for the Ni nitrate sample during the decomposition phase equals 15.9 % versus 37 % for the citrate sample. During decomposition of the former precursor, NOx and H2O are observed, whereas CO2 and H2O are observed for the latter with MS. The MS intensities for the decomposition products nicely correspond to the 1st derivative of the mass loss. These 1st derivative profiles also revealed two decomposition steps, marked I) and II). The drying and decomposition processes for the two samples are summarized in Table 1 . Starting with the Ni nitrate precursor, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O likely precipitates upon the evaporation of the solvent (water). These crystallites progressively dehydrate to Ni(NO3)2·2H2O between 30 and 60 °C. Aside from water, NO formation is observed from 60 °C onwards in frame c) associated with basic nickel nitrate formation. As water formation plateaus around 150 °C, the mass keeps decreasing in a linear fashion until 250 °C accompanied by a steady NO release. Hence, this mass loss is attributed to Ni(NO3)2·2H2O decomposition, denoted as decomposition phase I in frame a) and Table 1. The expected mass loss corresponds to shedding all the NO3 – ligands is −15.9 %. A −7.9 % mass loss was observed, thus approximately half of the NO3 – was lost in this region. Comparing these observations to literature, this decomposition phase can be ascribed to hydrolysis and evolution of Ni(NO3)2·2H2O to form hydroxynitrate phases; Nix(NO3)y(OH)z.[23,24]. Above 250 °C, a faster second decomposition step (II) is observed corresponding to 8.1 % of mass loss. This phase coincides with a spike in NO, NO2 evolution, a dip in H2O formation and is thus attributed to the decomposition of the Nix(NO3)y(OH)z to form NiO nuclei which consequently grow into nanoparticles; step II in Fig. 1 a) and Table 1 [12,25]. The dip in H2O signal during the decomposition is explained by reaction of NOx species with steam, forming gaseous HNO2/HNO3 that thus consume water. The drying step for the Ni citrate precursor differs from that of the Ni nitrate precursor as solely water is observed with MS until 150 °C in frame d). This is because citric acid does not evaporate at this temperature (boiling point ∼ 310 °C) and only decomposes into CO2 and H2O at temperatures > 175 °C. Thus, the 25 vol% citric acid impregnation solution dehydrates to form a citrate-based matrix in which Ni2+ species are embedded. Around 170 °C decomposition step I is observed in frame b) and Table 1, indicated by the mass loss from TGA and the increase in both CO2 and H2O. The mass lost in this step, between 150 and 240 °C, is −14 %. This would correspond to half of the citric acid impregnated (38 % expected mass loss), detailed in Table S1 . This decomposition step is associated with the combustion of the citrate matrix in which the Ni species reside. It is likely that CO forms due to incomplete combustion, but this cannot be proven due to overlap of CO and N2 carrier gas in the MS signal. An alternative explanation for this mass loss, could be the non-oxidative decarboxylation of citrate to citraconic anhydride (C5H4O3) corresponding to an expected −16 % mass loss [26]. The citrate ligands are denoted as C6H8-xO7 with x being 1, 2 or 3 depending on the degree of deprotonation. Since the pH of the impregnation solution was ∼ 2, x is likely to be 2–3 [27]. At higher temperatures, another major decomposition event occurs, equating to –22.9 % of mass loss; decomposition phase II with apex around 305 °C in frame b). The rapid nature of the mass loss and CO2 and H2O evolution are ascribed to oxidation of the citrate ligands by Ni [28]. The total mass lost in decomposition phase I & II equals 37 %, which is close to the expected mass loss of decomposition of all citric acid and the CO3 2– from the Ni precursor. The more important observation is that the decomposition process of the citrate matrix in which the Ni precursor resides and the total decomposition of the latter does not occur consecutively as is the case with the Ni nitrate precursor. The direct comparison of the drying and decomposition of the Ni nitrate and citrate precursors provides two major insights; A) Decomposition of the citrate matrix follows drying, thus the citric acid matrix keeps the Ni2+ in place, which is not the case for the Ni nitrate precursor. Therefore, the Ni citrate precursor cannot redistribute over the support as can be the case with Ni nitrate. B) Ni citrate precursor decomposition occurs much faster than Ni nitrate decomposition, which is associated with the respective exothermicity and the endothermicity of these decompositions. It is expected that the different precursor decomposition pathways findings translate to differences in metal distribution over the support after drying and decomposition. Note that these differences are expected after drying, since before drying, the pores are likely homogeneously filled with either precursor formulation (as was reported previously for metal nitrates) [29]. In Fig. 2 a)-f) Cryo-STEM images are shown of blank SBA-15 (a & b), and samples impregnated and dried with either Ni nitrate (c&d) or Ni citrate (e&h). Fig. 2 a), a view of the blank SBA-15 sample seen perpendicular to the pores, shows empty regularly ordered ∼ 7 nm diameter pores. In Fig. 2 b) the sample is shown parallel to the pores, showing the honeycomb arrangement of empty pores. Fig. 2 c) and d) show the Ni citrate impregnated and dried sample perpendicular and almost parallel to the pores respectively. In both images, there is little contrast between the filler precursor and the SBA-15 pore walls, demonstrating that most pores are uniformly filled. Fig. 2 e) and f) show the Ni nitrate impregnated viewed perpendicular and parallel to the pores respectively. The stark contrast differences between different pores in this sample, further emphasized with BF-TEM in Figure S2 , imply that a fraction of the pores is filled with precursor material whereas other pores are empty, which was previously reported by Eggenhuisen et al. for Ni nitrate and by Prieto et al. for Cu nitrate [29,30]. The differences in pore-filling of these samples was also evaluated with N2-physisorption ( Figure S3 and Table S3 ). The pore-volume of the Ni citrate sample was significantly smaller, supporting the Cryo-STEM observations. These results demonstrate that after drying, a drastically more uniform distribution of metal precursor over the pores was obtained with Ni citrate than with Ni nitrate. Fig. 2 g) and h) show STEM micrographs of the Ni citrate and Ni nitrate impregnated samples after drying and 450 °C heat treatment. The Ni citrate sample was treated in air to decompose the citrate ligands. The Ni nitrate sample was treated in NO/N2 to avoid severe sintering and formation of NiO plugs. In g), The < 2 nm NiO nanoparticles in the ex-citrate sample are seen homogeneously distributed over the SBA-15 pores. In contrast, in the ex-nitrate sample, some SBA-15 pores are empty and other pores are densely filled with NiO ∼ 2 nm nanoparticles. These observations demonstrate how the uniformity of the Ni-metal precursor distribution after drying directly translates to the final metal (oxide) nanoparticle distribution. Considering the combined results, we can explain why the Ni citrate precursor produces more homogeneously distributed Ni nanoparticles than the Ni nitrate precursor; After the water has evaporated, Ni2+ is immobilized in a citrate matrix that fills all pores uniformly, unlike with the nitrate precursor where mobile precursor species redistribute and concentrate in a fraction of the SBA-15 pores. Consequently, decomposition of the citrate precursor produces uniformly distributed Ni nanoparticles over the support whereas the distribution of Ni nanoparticles over the support using Ni nitrate as precursor is highly heterogenous. 3.2 Controlling the Pd-Ni atomic distribution The strength of citrate-based precursors to obtain a very uniform metal distribution over the support prompted us to explore citrate based precursors for bimetallic Pd-Ni nanoparticles, hoping that a controlled distribution of Pd and Ni precursors could result in a controlled Pd:Ni ratio per individual nanoparticle, critical for producing active and selective bimetallic catalysts. Therefore, Pd precursors were screened for their compatibility with the Ni citrate precursor discussed in the previous section. Pd(NO3)2xH2O was unsuitable because of its instability (the formation of black Pd precipitates) and PdCl2 was avoided as Cl species could promote or poison catalyst activity. Pd(OAc)2 and Pd(NH3)4(NO3)2 were compatible as these were soluble in the 25 vol% citric acid solution from the Ni citrate precursor. Considering the lower solubility of the former precursor we chose a 0.9 wt% Pd and 5 wt% Ni catalyst after impregnation, drying, calcination and reduction. This sample is further referred to as Pd-Ni Ac-Citr to designate the Pd precursor first and the Ni precursor second. The larger solubility of Pd(NH3)4(NO3)2 allowed us to produce a 1.8 wt% Pd and 10 wt% Ni catalyst after impregnation, drying, calcination and reduction. This sample is referred to as Pd-Ni NH3-Citr. The Pd:Ni molar ratio in both the Pd-Ni Ac-Citr and Pd-Ni NH3-Citr samples is 1:10. Inductively Coupled Plasma analysis confirmed that the metal loadings were similar to the targeted loadings, for the Ac-Citr sample: 0.86 wt% Pd and 4.76 wt% Ni and for the NH3-Citr sample: 1.76 wt% Pd and 9.74 wt% Ni. The decomposition behavior of the impregnated Pd-Ni samples was investigated with TGA-MS, shown in Fig. 3 . In a) and b) the TGA data for the Pd-Ni Ac-Citr and NH3-Citr samples are shown respectively. The TGA profiles resemble that of Ni citrate (in Fig. 1 b). The mass lost in phase I & II for the Pd-Ni Ac-Citr sample in Fig. 3 a) is almost equal to that lost for the Ni citrate sample in Fig. 1 b). However, the second decomposition step is more gradual for these bimetallic samples than for the monometallic citrate precursor sample, as is evidenced by the 1st derivative for the Pd-Ni Ac-Citr sample in Fig. 3 a). In contrast to the Pd-Ni Ac-Citr system, the TGA profile for the Pd-Ni NH3-Citr precursor in b) resembles that of Ni citrate, although there is a shoulder present, indicated with a dark blue arrow. Also, the second decomposition step for the bimetallic samples (Fig. 3 a and b), in which the Ni precursors are decomposed to form NiO nanoparticles, occurs at lower temperature, 270 and 290 °C respectively, compared to 305 °C for the monometallic Ni citrate sample. This is supported by the larger amount of CO2 to H2O generated around these temperatures. It is clear that the addition of Pd and the type of Pd precursor significantly change the decomposition profile. The fact that the Pd-Ni Ac-Citr precursor decomposes at lower temperature than the Pd-Ni NH3-Citr sample is explained by the more reducing nature of the acetate ligands than the amine ligands; The reducing acetate ligands are particularly exploited in the synthesis of metallic Pd at low temperatures [31]. The Pd nanoparticles formed at lower temperatures in the Pd-Ni Ac-Citr sample may thus catalyze decomposition of the citrate matrix. 3.3 Pd-Ni intimacy in the bimetallic catalysts H2-Temperature Programmed Reduction (TPR) was used to probe the intimacy of Pd and Ni phases of the 350 °C calcined Pd-Ni NH3-Citr and Pd-Ni Ac-Citr catalysts (Fig. 4 ). The reduction of the calcined monometallic NiO ex-citrate reference sample is represented by the blue line. The reduction of NiO to Ni0 spans a broad range, from 250 to 600 °C. The TPR profile representing the Pd-Ni Ac-Citr sample in red is similar. However, the Pd-Ni NH3-Citr sample shows two major reduction regimes, one between 100 and 280 °C and another between 280 and 520 °C. The former, equal to 43 % of H2 uptake, is associated with reduction of NiO promoted by Pd0. The most probable reason for this is that metallic Pd can efficiently chemisorb hydrogen to reduce proximate NiO.5 Additionally, the presence of Pd0 seeds may lower the energy of formation required to produce Ni0 nuclei. The second regime, equating to 57 % of H2 uptake, is associated with NiO species probably more isolated from metallic Pd. These results show that the type of Pd precursor has a large effect on the intimacy between Pd and Ni. In Fig. 5 a) BF-TEM for the Pd-Ni NH3-Citr sample after reduction at 450 °C is shown. The nanoparticles sized 3.4 ± 0.4 nm are uniformly distributed over the support. The nanoparticles of the Pd-Ni Ac-Citr sample (frame b), are larger; 4.3 ± 0.5 nm. The lower density of nanoparticles per pore in the latter sample is a result of the 50 % lower loading of Pd and Ni due to the lower solubility of Pd(OAc)2. In Fig. 5 c) and d) HAADF-STEM micrographs are shown in which it is easier to distinguish between the metallic nanoparticles and the silica support. This confirms the uniformity of nanoparticle distribution over the support. Powder X-ray Diffraction was used as complementary technique and showed no evidence for the presence of larger Pd and/or Ni crystallites, detailed in Section S4 of the supplementary information. Hence, it is evident that the citrate precursor is effective to achieve a uniform distribution of nanoparticles over the support irrespective of whether this is a monometallic Ni or bimetallic Pd-Ni catalyst. To investigate the atomic distribution of the Pd and Ni in the bimetallic samples, X-ray Absorption Spectroscopy (XAS) was employed for the samples reduced at 450 °C and slightly passivated in air before the measurement. In Fig. 6 a) Pd-K edge XANES spectra are shown for the Pd-Ni NH3-Citr, Pd-Ni Ac-Citr, Pd0 and PdO reference samples. The spectrum of the Pd-Ni NH3-Citr sample shows a more intense white line peak at the Pd-K edge than the Pd-Ni Ac-Citr sample, whereas the Pd in the latter sample has an edge jump at lower energies, meaning that the Pd in this sample is more reduced. The differences between these samples are more clearly reflected in b) the Fourier Transformed (FT) EXAFS data. The Pd-O and Pd-Pd radial distances were determined from the relevant references as 1.90 Å and 2.75 Å respectively. The bimetallic Pd-Ni samples exhibit no clear scattering path at 2.75 Å, instead two overlapping scattering paths are observed in this region; Pd scatters to Ni at ∼ 2.64 Å and to Pd at ∼ 2.69 Å [32]. The localized environment surrounding the absorbing Pd atoms was quantified by fitting the experimentally acquired FT EXAFS data using using Crystallographic Information File (cif) references from the materials project; Pd(0) (mp-2), Pd(II)O (mp-10728) and Pd-Ni (mp-1220057). This is further detailed in Table S5 and Figure S5 [33]. For the Pd-Ni Ac-Citr sample, the coordination numbers (CN) for Pd-O, Pd-Pd and Pd-Ni were 1.3, 2.1 and 4.9 respectively. We believe that the Pd-O bonding arises from passivation in air before XAS measurement, as reduction at 450 °C would have produced solely metallic Pd0 species [34]. For the Pd-Ni NH3-Citr sample, the coordination numbers for Pd-Ni and Pd-Pd were 4.5 and 4.7 respectively. Comparing the fitted coordination numbers with the maximum coordination numbers provides insight regarding the average Pd size and degree of Pd-Ni interaction. For bulk face cubic centered Pd and Ni the max CN is 12 [35]. However, for the 4.3 and 3.4 nm average nanoparticle sizes for the Pd-Ni Ac-Citr and NH3-Citr sample, we expect a total coordination number (CNmax) of 10, see calculation in S5. The Pd-O scattering in the Ac-Citr sample complicates fitting, but it is clear that the CNPd-Ni is smaller in this sample than in the NH3-Citr sample. For the NH3-Citr sample, the total CN for Pd-Pd and Pd-Ni scattering from the EXAFS fit (CNfit) matches the expected CNmax; 9.26 versus 9.95 respectively. Hence more than 50 % of the metallic Pd present appears to be bound to Ni. So the EXAFS fits suggest that Pd and Ni are significantly segregated in the Pd-Ni Ac-Citr sample and well-mixed in the NH3-Citr sample. To show how the Pd and Ni are spatially distributed over the nanoparticles in the samples, elemental mapping (STEM-EDX) was used. In the STEM images of Fig. 7 a) and d) for the Pd-Ni Ac-Citr and Pd-Ni NH3-Citr samples respectively, the pores of the SBA-15 support are clearly visible with the nanoparticles inside. The EDX map corresponding to the Pd-Ni Ac-Citr sample in b) shows that the ∼ 4.3 nanoparticles mostly consist of Pd, with the Ni being uniformly distributed as small clusters (<2 nm) over the pores. The white arrow in the EDX map indicates a line-scan over two nanoparticles for which the Pd, Ni and Si spectrum-quantified profiles are shown in c). In Fig. 7 d) the HAADF-STEM image for the Pd-Ni NH3-Citr sample is shown. The EDX map corresponding to the STEM image in e) shows that the Pd and Ni are present in almost every single nanoparticle. This is further emphasized in the line-scan in f), where an increase in Pd signal is met with an increase in Ni. Close comparison of the EDX maps of both samples, clearly shows that the Pd-Ni nanoparticles in the Pd-Ni NH3-Citr sample are bimetallic in nature, whereas mostly monometallic Pd nanoparticles and separate Ni clusters are present in the Ac-Citr sample (like those shown with HAADF-STEM for the monometallic sample in Fig. 2 g). Hence, the STEM-EDX results are in agreement with the observations from H2-TPR and EXAFS, showing that the Pd and Ni are mixed in each nanoparticle in the Pd-Ni NH3-Citr sample and segregated in the Pd-Ni Ac-Citr catalyst. The fact that the Pd-Ni nanoparticles in the NH3-Citr sample are larger than in the monometallic Ni catalyst is explained by the higher metal loading (an additional 1.8 wt% Pd), which helps in increasing the particle size during nucleation and growth. Additionally, the type of precursor and decomposition products can impact the mobility of metal species during heat treatment (which can be mitigated using NO atmosphere when using Ni nitrates) [23,36,37]. 3.4 Influence of Pd-Ni atomic distribution on CO2 hydrogenation The bimetallic catalysts were tested for CO2 hydrogenation to study how the Pd-Ni atomic distribution impacted the catalytic performance. Ni is generally more active than Pd for CO or CO2 hydrogenation [38,39]. If indeed the NH3-Citr has a greater Pd-to-Ni intimacy than the Ac-Citr sample, the former should be less active than the latter. And the monometallic Ni Citr reference should be more active as well. The CO2 conversion versus time is shown in Figure S6.1 . In Fig. 8 a), the activity is compared for the different catalysts. The activity is normalized to the mass of Ni, because of the 10:1 Ni:Pd ratio in the bimetallic samples and the absence of Pd in the reference. The activity is approximately 2x larger for the the separate Pd and Ni nanoparticles in the Ac-Citr sample and the monometallic Ni than the bimetallic Pd-Ni nanoparticles in the NH3-Citr sample. These results demonstrate that CO2 hydrogenation activity can be used as characterization technique to probe the Pd-Ni intimacy. To take into account the different nanoparticle sizes of the catalysts, the Turn-Over-Frequency (TOF; in molCO2 × s−1 × molMetal,surface -1) values are shown in the plot. These TOF values are in line with literature values for Ni catalysts operated under similar conditions [40]. Moreover, the TOF comparison confirms that the segregated Pd and Ni nanoparticles are significantly more active than the bimetallic Pd-Ni nanoparticles in the NH3-Citr sample. Regarding the selectivity of the catalysts in figure b), the samples containing Pd have a slightly lower selectivity to CH4 in favor of CO. The change in activity and selectivity over time is likely related to a typical stabilization period within the first 10 h of operation [40]. The catalysts were studied post-catalysis with TEM ( Figure S6.2 ) to assess their stability. Sintering of metal nanoparticles and loss of mesoporosity was observed in some areas, but overall the nanoparticle size resembled the fresh catalysts. It is clear that the addition of palladium to nickel decreases the CO2 hydrogenation activity of the nanoparticles. A probable explanation is the perturbation of the Ni electronic structure by close proximity with Pd, which also explains the increase in the selectivity to CO. This is supported by literature as palladium is active for the reverse water gas shift reaction CO2 + H2 → CO + H2O, whilst nickel is a potent CO2 to CH4 hydrogenation catalyst [4,6,41,42]. Alternatively, the surface of the nanoparticles may be more enriched with Pd due to a stronger interaction of Pd with CO than for Ni [43]. These results show that the method of making such bimetallic catalysts with 1:10 Pd:Ni molar ratio has a profound effect on their catalytic performance. Potentially, the reported approach here can be extended to other supports, depending on compatibility with incipient wetness impregnation (the presence of sufficient porosity). However, specifically for nickel on carbon, the high reduction temperature required to reduce NiO in H2 ( ≥ 450 °C) may lead to carbon methanation [44]. 4 Conclusion The drying and decomposition mechanisms of impregnated Ni citrate and Ni nitrate precursor were analyzed. The Ni citrate precursor inhibited severe redistribution − seen with the nitrate precursor − and thus translated to homogeneous nanoparticle distribution in the activated catalyst. The same strategy was applied to produce uniformly distributed Pd-Ni nanoparticles. The choice of Pd precursor, Pd(OAc)2 or Pd(NH3)4(NO3)2, greatly impacted the extent of Pd and Ni mixings. The former produced segregated Pd nanoparticles and Ni clusters whereas the latter produced bimetallic Pd-Ni nanoparticles. The Pd-Ni Ac-Citr catalyst demonstrated higher CO2 hydrogenation activity than the Pd-Ni NH3-Citr catalyst. This work presents guidelines for the preparation of homogeneously distributed Pd-Ni nanoparticles in which the Pd:Ni ratio and Pd-Ni intimacy can be controlled. coredata.dc:description: Bimetallic supported catalysts can show synergistic effects compared to their monometallic constituents. However, it is challenging to produce bimetallic catalysts with a uniform nanoparticle distribution over the support, while ensuring each nanoparticle contains both metals. A promising strategy is to use impregnation precursors that facilitate uniform distribution of both metals over a support. In this work, citrate-based precursors were studied to prepare bimetallic Pd-Ni nanoparticles supported on SBA-15 mesoporous silica. Amongst others, cryo-electron microscopy demonstrated the excellent distribution of Ni citrate precursor after drying. Co-impregnation with Ni citrate precursor and Pd(OAc)2 or Pd(NH3)4(NO3)2 produced well-distributed Pd-Ni nanoparticles with a narrow particle size distribution. Extensive characterization with STEM-EDX, EXAFS and TPR showed that the type of Pd precursor controlled the Pd to Ni nanoscale intimacy. CO2 hydrogenation experiments demonstrated that increasing Pd-Ni intimacy decreased the activity. Our strategy to produce uniform Pd-Ni nanoparticles using citric acid is relevant also for other bimetallic systems.
